text:
News Tories bussed in to Parliament from lavish ball to defeat Labour's bid for more Brexit scrutiny Several Cabinet ministers were spotted on board a 24-seater German-made Mercedes bus as it arrived at the Black and White Ball Share Tory ministers including Karen Bradley and Chris Grayling arrive on a minibus at the Tory Black and White Ball (Photo: Mirror/Mikey Smith) Share Get politics   
Top Tories were bussed into Parliament tonight from their lavish annual fundraiser to defeat Labour's bid for more Brexit scrutiny. 
Several Cabinet ministers were spotted on board a 24-seater German-made Mercedes bus as it arrived at the Black and White Ball. 
The bash with millionaire donors in London's Battersea Park was inconveniently scheduled on the first night of committee votes on the Government's Article 50 Bill. 
That meant MPs had to return at 9pm to vote on Jeremy Corbyn 's demand that the Prime Minister reports on her negotiations every two months. Read More 9 little things we learned from the Brexit White Paper... and 9 big things we didn't 
Labour triggered the vote 10 minutes early - but Tory MPs made it back in time to ensure the amendment was defeated 333-284. 
The minibus was seen leaving the ball with around half an hour to spare, followed swiftly by the Prime Minister in an official car. Theresa May sat next to Boris Johnson when the vote result was announced 
Top-flight Tories seen arriving at the party on the bus included Michael Gove, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, Justice Secretary Liz Truss and Chief Secretary to the Treasury David Gauke. 
Also spotted on board were Transport Secretary Chris Grayling, party chairman Patrick McLoughlin and Culture Secretary Karen Bradley. 
It was unclear if the same Tory MPs were on the bus when it returned to Parliament. 
Theresa May had pushed the votes back by more than an hour, giving her MPs more time to party. Another vote was due at midnight. 
She returned to the Commons chamber dressed all in black, with a black tuxedo-style jacket, heavy chain link-style necklace and glittering bracelet. 
She chatted and laughed with Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Disabilities Minister Penny Mordaunt while the votes were counted. The venue where the Black and White Ball took place - but the Mirror wasn't allowed in (Photo: Mirror/Mikey Smith) 
One MP not wearing a tie briefly came and chatted to the Prime Minister on the green benches. 
Dozens of Tory MPs including Mr Johnson then left en masse after the result was announced at 9pm. 
Asked if he’d enjoyed the ball so far, Mr Johnson replied: “Very good!” 
The Black and White Ball is a much anticipated fixture on the Conservative calendar, but was reportedly rebranded the Black and White 'Party' this year in a bid to look less out-of-touch. 
This year's event was opened up to some activists paying just £75 each and guests were told not to worry about wearing black tie. 
It appeared MPs paid heed, sporting regular suits and not bow ties in the Commons chamber. 
But other die-hard Tories rocked up to quaff pricey claret in bow ties and glittering gowns. 
The highlight of the event, which a source said would be compered by former Tory minister and TV presenter Esther McVey, is the auction. Last year four Tory election posters were auctioned off for £50,000 
In previous years items on the block have included a shoe shopping trip with Theresa May herself, along with lush holidays and rounds of grouse shooting at swanky hotels. 
Last year four Tory campaign posters were flogged for £50,000, a day of campaigning with Zac Goldsmith went for £35,000 and the raffle was drawn by Samantha Cameron. Read More Inside the Tory Black and White Ball: Booze, tycoons and bizarre auctions at the top secret fundraiser 
Tonight Parliament saw the first of three nights of debate on the Bill allowing the PM to trigger Brexit , with a final vote on Wednesday night. 
Labour MPs were in uproar after they were denied the chance to vote on other amendments, including on the European Arrest Warrant and single market. 
Chris Leslie fumed: “We’ve had a knife in proceedings curtailing not just debate but our opportunity for the House to vote on incredibly important things.” 
Wes Streeting added: “What can we do to make sure the public are aware we are taking our scrutiny seriously?” 
Deputy Speaker Natascha Engel hit back that it was her decision - adding: “That is very close to challenging the decision of the chair." Like us on Facebook
